Bangalore is getting flying electric taxis! 🚁⚡

While Silicon Valley had its self-driving cars, 

Bangalore is taking urban mobility to the skies with flying taxis.

Bangalore International Airport Limited (BIAL) just announced a groundbreaking partnership with Sarla Aviation to introduce electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) aircraft.

This is set to make Kempegowda International Airport India’s first eVTOL-friendly airport.

And it’s not just a cool concept—it’s going to change your daily commute 👇

Here’s how it works:

🚗 A trip from Indiranagar to the airport that normally takes 1.5 hours…
✈️ …will now take just 5 minutes.

Yes, 5 minutes instead of battling through endless traffic! 🤯

But that’s not all…

This futuristic ride is also cheaper than your current taxi fare. 💰

 • Taxi fare today: ₹2,500 (with surge)
 • Flying taxi fare: ₹1,700

You’re getting there faster, cheaper, and in an eco-friendly way. 🌱 These electric aircraft run on clean energy, produce minimal noise, and create zero emissions.

The best part?

The eVTOLs will accommodate 7 passengers, fly at 250 km/h, and cover 160 km on a single charge.

With plans to offer ride-sharing services similar to Uber and Ola, flying to the airport will soon be as easy as booking a cab. 🚖➡️✈️

But, there’s a catch…

Before these flying taxis take over, we still need regulatory approvals and infrastructure development, 

which could take another 2 years.

Would you line up to give flying taxi a shot?

🚨 Rupee hits all-time low at ₹84.07 vs USD. Here is how it affects you and me 👇

To start with, let's understand why it's happening.

1️⃣ Foreign Investors are Fleeing

This year alone, $28.4 billion has been pulled out from Indian markets. With so much dollar demand, the rupee’s getting squeezed.

2️⃣ Global Uncertainty is Crushing Us

Geopolitical tensions (Ukraine, anyone?) have investors running to ‘safe’ currencies like the US dollar, leaving the rupee to drop. 🌍

3️⃣ Crude Oil Prices are Sky-High

India imports over 80% of its crude oil, and with oil still hovering above $100 per barrel, our import bills are spiking. 🛢️

4️⃣ Inflation is Eating Away at Us

With the rupee falling, imported goods are getting pricier. You’ve probably already noticed your monthly budget taking a hit. 🛒

So, how does this affect us (people in India)?

💸 Higher Cost of Living

Expect prices for fuel, groceries, and everyday goods to climb. It’s already happening, and it’s not slowing down.

🎓 Studying Abroad? 

Get Ready for a Price Hike
With a weaker rupee, foreign education is getting even more expensive. 

Your dream of sending your kids abroad just got costlier.

📉 Businesses Are Under Pressure

Companies that rely on imports or have foreign loans are feeling the heat, and this could slow down growth across industries.

Rising living costs are hitting hard, and we need some serious action. 

Will the government step in with reforms to stabilize the rupee?

What do YOU think India’s next move should be to tackle this crisis? 

Let’s discuss 👇

MrBeast and Logan Paul are in India to launch Feastables and Prime drink 🔥

It's going to be game changer, here is why 👇

1. Global powerhouses, local impact:

Combined, they’ve got millions of subscribers worldwide, with India as their top viewer base.

Fun fact: 30% of YouTube’s viewership comes from India—which makes this launch a no-brainer for these creators.

2. Massive valuations and revenue numbers:

MrBeast’s Feastables already racks up millions of dollars in revenue.

Prime, Logan’s hydration drink, has a valuation over $3-5 billion dollars 

By tapping into their massive Indian following, they’re set to grow even bigger 📈

3. Perfect timing for new markets:

Unlike the U.S., India’s energy drink and premium chocolate markets are still relatively untapped.

Prime and Feastables are already available on Amazon and Blinkit for around 500 rupees—a 10x markup!

Once these products hit at regular prices, think 50-100 rupees, they’re bound to sell like hot cakes.

4. Impact on India’s creator economy:

By bringing their brands to India, they’re not just selling products; they’re paving the way for Indian creators to monetize like never before.

If this model works, expect more global creator brands to start making India a priority market.

With Feastables and Prime on the ground, the era of creators building billion-dollar brands in India might just be beginning. 🚀

What do you think? 

Could this change the future of creator-led brands in India? 

Would you try Prime and Feastables once they launch in India?

5,000 employees of Swiggy to make 8000 crores 🤯

Here is how

You all know that Swiggy is going public but this isn’t just another IPO. 

It’s a game-changer for employee wealth in India’s startup scene. 

Swiggy has designed its ESOP policy to be one of the most lucrative and inclusive out there—and here’s why it’s blowing minds across the industry.

You see, Swiggy’s ESOP structure has a unique feature that’s hard to find in other companies: it includes everyone. 

There’s a structured model for distributing ESOPs, meaning employees across levels and even former employees keep their vested shares. 

At one point in 2019, Swiggy employed over 12,000 people. 

Today, that number is down to about 5,500, but even those who have moved on still retain their vested options. 

Compare that to most startups, where only a select few receive stock options, and this becomes truly rare.

But it’s not just about access. 

The terms are equally enticing. 

Unlike competitors like Zomato that back-load vesting over four years, Swiggy’s ESOPs vest evenly, giving employees 25% each year. 

This way, every year counts—and so does every employee’s commitment.

Why does this matter so much now? 

Swiggy’s IPO is about to be one of India’s biggest wealth events for employees.

With close to 230 million ESOPs, valued at over ₹8,960 crore ($1.06 billion), 
thousands of employees are on the brink of life-changing gains. 

And here’s a twist: 

Swiggy secured a rare exemption from SEBI to allow employees to sell shares just one month after the IPO, creating instant liquidity. 

People are already talking about how they’ll invest their new wealth—from launching startups and paying off student loans to buying real estate in Bangalore.

For a startup community used to high turnover, 

Swiggy’s focus on employees goes deep. 

Founder Harsha Majety made it a priority early on. 

Hiring Girish Menon as CHRO in 2016 was a turning point—he came with experience from Flipkart and HSBC, and since then, 

Swiggy has built a people-first approach to growth. 

Even as the company faced cuts and tightened its budget to boost profitability, it kept the team’s long-term wealth in mind. 

It’s a move that’s lowered Swiggy’s wage bill from 18% of total expenses in 2022 to 14% in 2024, a critical step as it approaches public markets.

So, are we witnessing a new era of employee wealth creation in India’s startup landscape? 

Or is Swiggy just an outlier in a sea of more selective ESOP policies?

Let’s dive into it—would love to hear your thoughts! 👇

Essential Math fundamentals you should know to build a career in AI.

1. Linear Algebra

Essential for understanding data structures like vectors and matrices, which are everywhere in AI.

Topics: Vectors, matrices, matrix multiplication, eigenvalues, eigenvectors.

2. Calculus 

Necessary for understanding optimization, which helps AI models learn.

Topics: Derivatives, gradients, partial derivatives, chain rule.

3. Probability & Statistics 

Core for making sense of data, especially in fields like machine learning and NLP.

Topics: Probability distributions, descriptive and inferential statistics, Bayes’ theorem, hypothesis testing.

4. Optimization 

Central to training models by finding the best parameters.

Topics: Gradient descent, convex optimization, loss functions.

5. Discrete Mathematics 

Useful for understanding algorithms and logic in computer science.

Topics: Graph theory, combinatorics, logic and set theory

6. Linear and Logistic Regression 

Regression techniques are foundational for supervised learning.

Topics: Linear relationships, least squares, sigmoid function for logistic regression.

Don't start learning fancy frameworks (PyTorch, Langchain etc.) without knowing these essential fundamentals.

Pros and Cons of Life in the USA

Based on my personal experiences and observations over the past 17 years.

PROS

1. Access to nature right in your backyard. Clean air.

2. A culture of innovation and the opportunity to work with some of the smartest people from around the world.

3. Private space to work distraction-free, with freedom over your personal choices.

4. Better civic sense, law, and order.

5. Financial benefit—especially when visiting India, where the exchange rate multiplies your money by 80.

CONS

1. Visa issues create constant stress. It took 14 years for me to get my green card due to the backlog for India.

2. Poor food quality. Vegetables and other ingredients lack their original taste. Eating stale, frozen food is common.

3. Social isolation, which can be stressful, especially during sickness or challenges.

4. Lack of thrill. Life feels predictable, like a for-loop: Weekdays—work, kids' classes, walk, sleep. Weekends—Costco/Patel brother visits, cleaning, birthday parties, temple visits. While this may be true in India as well, in the USA it is extreme

5. No concept of bai (maid). You are your own Ramukaka and Shantabai 

Ultimately, happiness is very subjective. It depends on your personality, goals, and experiences. Some people are happy and content, while others regret not moving back.

How has your experience in the USA been so far?
